awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Ecosystems on the Edge - Tidal wetland-estuary margins as buffers, reactors, and transformers of organic carbon and nitrogen
awd_abstract_narration:
Tidal wetlands are among the most productive, diverse and economically important ecosystems on Earth.  They are also especially vulnerable to human pressures and environmental change. Wetlands contain large reservoirs of soil organic matter, an important source of carbon and nitrogen to estuaries and coastal oceans, but very little is known about the processes involved in the translocation of these nutrients. This project will advance understanding of tidal marsh-estuarine interactions by linking processes between tidal wetland soils and estuaries, and assessing where, when, and how dissolved organic compounds are retained, released and transformed within the marsh soil-estuarine system. Results from this study will be integrated into enhanced monitoring and management efforts through partnerships with the Environmental Protection Agency, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the National Estuarine Research Reserve System. The project will improve models that predict the influence of wetlands on estuarine and coastal biology,  geochemistry and pollution response.  In collaboration with the Smithsonian Citizen Science program and teachers from middle schools serving minority students, the team will develop K-12 educational materials.  Specialized training will be extended to undergraduate students, as well as graduate and postdoctoral researchers, with a particular focus on underrepresented groups in science. 

This study will test three key research hypotheses that are critical for understanding the role of marsh soils and tidal wetland-estuary margins as buffers, reactors, and transformers of dissolved organic C and N, and that could transform our ability to predict the influence of wetland ecosystems on estuarine biology, biogeochemistry, and ecology. An integrative approach will be used to test hypotheses that combines rich datasets, process-focused experiments, and a novel coupled hydrodynamic-photo-biogeochemical model to investigate three understudied aspects of marsh export that likely control the seasonality and fate of dissolved organic matter in estuaries: (i) soil and porewater organic matter composition, (ii) adsorption-desorption on soil surfaces, and iii) photo- and bio- degradation in estuarine waters. Proposed activities incorporate a system perspective and cover a broad range of marsh environments (i.e., different marsh vegetation characteristics, soil type, surface area and salinity regimes) providing the ability to scale up and assess tidal marsh biogeochemical fluxes and processes across a range of spatial and temporal scales.  Results from this research will increase understanding of the contributions of wetlands and estuarine systems to coastal carbon and nitrogen budgets, and improve predictions of the influences of natural and man-made stresses on ecosystem processes, biogeochemical cycles and exchanges along the continuum of wetlands, estuaries and the coastal zone. This information is highly valuable to managing the coastal zone in the face of accelerated environmental change and continued human pressures and, in particular, to evaluating the potential for managed restoration of wetlands to mitigate climate change impacts.

por.por_cntn:
Wetlands are among the most productive, diverse, and economically important ecosystems on Earth, contributing approximately $47 trillion USD per year in ecosystem services or 45 percent of the value of all natural biomes on our planet. On the land-water interface, tidal wetlands are also especially vulnerable to human pressures and environmental change. Increasingly, tidal wetlands are being recognized for their important role in carbon sequestration and, when degraded, their potential to release centuries to millennia of ‘blue carbon’ accumulated in soils. Yet little is known about the physical and biological processes that affect these large carbon reservoirs (tidal marsh soils) and regulate the quantity and quality of carbon exported to adjacent waters, estuaries, and the coastal ocean.

 

This project provided new insight on tidal marsh-estuarine interactions by linking processes between tidal wetland soils and estuaries, and assessing where, when, and how dissolved organic compounds are retained, released, and transformed within the marsh soil-estuarine system. Three key research hypotheses were tested that are critical for understanding the role of marsh soils and tidal wetland-estuary margins as buffers, reactors, and transformers of dissolved organic carbon (DOC), and that could transform our ability to predict the influence of wetland ecosystems on estuarine and coastal biology, biogeochemistry, ecology and pollution response. An integrative approach was used to test hypotheses that combined rich datasets, process-focused experiments, and a novel coupled hydrodynamic-photo-biogeochemical model to investigate three understudied aspects of marsh export that likely control the seasonality and fate of dissolved organic matter in estuaries: (i) soil and porewater organic matter composition, (ii) adsorption-desorption on soil surfaces, and iii) photo- and bio- degradation in estuarine waters.

 

This study evaluated the sources of wetland soil organic matter (OM) and found that estuarine materials made-up 30–50% of the soil OM while marsh plants contributed 40–70% of the OM. Relative contributions from these sources varied depending on location in the marsh. We also found that the organic matter composition of porewater DOC was distinct from the soils. We found that that adsorption-desorption to marsh soils regulates the total amount of DOC in tidal marsh waters and its composition. Humic (colored) DOC is selectively adsorbed to these soils with a high affinity that can displace non-colored soil organic matter. The strength of this selection depends on salinity, with higher salinity favoring more replacement. Moreover, the affinity of soils for humic DOC varies and adsorption-desorption reactions can change both the colored and non-colored fractions of DOC. Detailed chemical analysis also suggests that soils may act as a reactor, influencing the molecular composition of marsh porewater, contributing to smaller variation in DOC quality within a marsh system (i.e., seasonally and spatially) than between marsh systems, with differences between marsh systems driven mainly by the marsh plant community. Our photochemical and microbial degradation experiments using leachates from fresh and senescent wetland plants, showed clear differences with senescent material leaching both more DOC and a greater total of biodegradable DOC (despite a smaller fraction of labile DOC). Due to these distinctions between the fresh and senescent material, DOM quality and quantity may also shift seasonally and in response to climate change. Long term  measurements at the Chesapeake Bay Global Change Research Wetland –extending over a period of 4 years– allowed us to assess seasonal and inter-annual variation in the quality and quantity of DOM export from this temperate brackish wetland, and highlighted (i) that changes in the quantity and quality of DOM export from the marsh was smaller than the seasonal and inter-annual variation in plan production - the ultimate source of these compounds, consistent with our hypothesis that tidal marsh soils buffer seasonal and inter-annual variation in marsh DOC export; and (ii) extreme events, such as intense storms, disproportionally impact wetland DOC export to estuaries.

 

Results from this study have been integrated into enhanced monitoring and management efforts through partnerships with the Environmental Protection Agency, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the National Estuarine Research Reserve System. Educational materials have been developed, including for a minority (both black and Hispanic) serving institution, on the role of wetlands in coastal biogeochemical cycles under current and changing environmental conditions. Specialized training was extended to undergraduate students, as well as graduate and postdoctoral researchers, with a particular focus on underrepresented groups in science. Results from this research will increase understanding of the contributions of wetlands and estuarine systems to coastal carbon and nitrogen budgets, and improve predictions of the influences of natural and man-made stresses on ecosystem processes, biogeochemical cycles and exchanges along the continuum of wetlands, estuaries and the coastal zone. This information is highly valuable to managing the coastal zone in the face of accelerated environmental change and continued human pressures and, in particular, to evaluating the potential for managed restoration of wetlands to mitigate climate change impacts.
